case_vignette: A 68-year-old white man presents with 4 weeks of progressively worsening thickening of the skin and plaques on the bilateral nipple and areola. He has no personal or family history of warts or epidermal nevi and has not had hormonal therapy. On examination, he has hyperpigmented, verrucous plaques bilaterally, with no associated erythema or lymphadenopathy. Skin biopsy shows hyperkeratosis with papillomatosis. Corticosteroid treatment failed, but there was some minor improvement with calcipotriol after several weeks of use.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have been having thickened skin and rough patches on both of my nipples and the area around them for about a month.
Is this condition associated with any itching or pain?
No, there's no itching or pain.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 68-year-old man.
Have you been diagnosed with any underlying medical conditions or taking any medications?
No, I haven't been diagnosed with warts or skin growths before, and I'm not on hormonal therapy.
Is this condition affecting only the nipple area or spreading to other parts of the body?
It's only affecting the nipple area and the surrounding part.
Final Diagnosis: Nipple Eczema or Psoriasis. Further evaluation may be needed for confirmation.
